chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation
sanskrit:
तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत ।
तत्प्रसादात्परां शान्तिं स्थानं प्राप्स्यसि शाश्वतम् ॥
transliteration:
tam eva śaraṇaṁ gaccha sarvabhāvena bhārata |
tat-prasādāt parāṁ śāntiṁ sthānaṁ prāpsyasi śāśvatam ||
translation: Take refuge in Him alone with all your being, O Bharata. By His grace, you shall attain supreme peace and the eternal abode.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna gives Arjuna the ultimate instruction of complete surrender (śaraṇāgati). After eighteen chapters of profound philosophical discourse covering karma yoga, jñāna yoga, bhakti yoga, and various paths to liberation, Krishna distills the essence into this simple yet profound teaching: surrender completely to the Supreme Lord with one's entire being. The phrase 'sarvabhāvena' (with all your being) emphasizes total, unconditional surrender—not partial or conditional devotion, but complete dedication of body, mind, and soul.

This verse comes near the conclusion of the Gita and represents the culmination of Krishna's teaching. It follows the revelation that the Supreme Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings and controls the cosmic order. By taking complete refuge in that Supreme Reality, Arjuna is promised two fruits: 'parāṁ śāntiṁ' (supreme peace) and 'sthānaṁ śāśvatam' (the eternal abode). The supreme peace refers to the tranquility that comes from complete trust and surrender, while the eternal abode signifies moksha or liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

Philosophically, this verse represents the bhakti (devotional) culmination of the Gita's teaching. While the text has presented various paths—action, knowledge, and devotion—this verse emphasizes that ultimate refuge in the Divine through complete surrender is the most accessible and effective means to liberation. The assurance 'tat-prasādāt' (by His grace) indicates that liberation is not merely the result of human effort but comes through divine grace when one surrenders completely.
speaker: Krishna
